node.title: Jason Mott Wins National Book Award for ‘Hell of a Book’
node.alt: Jason Mott won the National Book Award for fiction for “Hell of a Book.”
node.description: Tiya Miles won the nonfiction prize for “All That She Carried.” The author Karen Tei Yamashita received a lifetime achievement award.
node.content: ["Jason Mott won the National Book Award for fiction on Wednesday for his novel \u201cHell of a Book,\u201d an account of a Black author\u2019s book tour intertwined with one focused on a Black boy in the rural South and a third character, The Kid, who may be imaginary.", "Mr. Mott, a poet and author who said in his speech that his agent had picked his work out of the unsolicited \u201cslush\u201d pile 10 years ago, has published three previous novels. ", "\u201cI would like to dedicate this award to all the other mad kids, to all the outsiders, the weirdos, the bullied,\u201d Mr. Mott said in his speech. \u201cThe ones so strange they had no choice but to be misunderstood by the world and by those around them. The ones who, in spite of this, refuse to outgrow their imagination, refuse to abandon their dreams and refuse to deny, diminish their identity, or their truth, or their loves, unlike so many others.\u201d", "The historian Tiya Miles won the nonfiction prize for \u201cAll That She Carried: The Journey of Ashley\u2019s Sack, a Black Family Keepsake.\u201d It traces the history of a family through a cotton sack that an enslaved woman gave to her daughter in the 19th century when they were about to be sold apart.", "The judges called it \u201ca brilliant, original work,\u201d examining a compilation of lives \u201cthat ordinary archives suppress.\u201d Dr. Miles, a professor at Harvard University, was awarded a MacArthur \u201cgenius\u201d grant in 2011.", "The National Book Award is one of the most closely watched literary prizes in the world, previously awarded to luminaries such as William Faulkner, W.H. Auden and Ralph Ellison. It can boost book sales and transform an author\u2019s profile.", "This year\u2019s ceremony was hosted by Phoebe Robinson, a comedian and the founder of Tiny Reparations Books, an imprint at Penguin Random House devoted to diverse voices. Her most recent book, \u201cPlease Don\u2019t Sit on My Bed in Your Outside Clothes,\u201d was published in September.", "This was the second annual National Book Awards ceremony held remotely because of the coronavirus pandemic, with Ms. Robinson recording from the Penguin Random House headquarters in New York City and authors and presenters beaming in remotely. In years past, hundreds of attendees celebrated at a black-tie gala at Cipriani Wall Street.", "\u201cIf there were ever a time that underscored the extraordinary experiences that books provide,\u201d said Ruth Dickey, the executive director of the National Book Foundation, \u201cit has been these past 20 months.\u201d", "The finalists for the fiction award included \u201cMatrix,\u201d by Lauren Groff, about an orphaned young woman who transforms a destitute nunnery; \u201cCloud Cuckoo Land,\u201d by Anthony Doerr, a novel that encompasses several centuries, two continents and one interstellar ship; \u201cZorrie,\u201d by Laird Hunt, a portrait of a woman\u2019s life in rural Indiana; and \u201cThe Prophets,\u201d by Robert Jones Jr., a love story about two enslaved men set on an antebellum plantation.", "Nonfiction finalists included \u201cA Little Devil in America,\u201d an essay collection by Hanif Abdurraqib celebrating Black performers and artists; \u201cRunning Out,\u201d by Lucas Bessire, about a Kansas aquifer at risk of depletion and its impact on the area\u2019s farmers and ranchers; \u201cTastes Like War,\u201d a memoir by Grace M. Cho, who cooks family recipes while exploring how war, xenophobia and colonialism are carried in the body; and \u201cCovered With Night,\u201d by Nicole Eustace, about the 18th-century murder case of an Indigenous hunter.", "Mart\u00edn Espada won the award for poetry for \u201cFloaters,\u201d a book that honors migrants who drowned in the Rio Grande. Judges said it was \u201cvital for our times and will be vital for those in the future, trying to make sense of today.\u201d", "The award for translated literature went to \u201cWinter in Sokcho\u201d a debut novel by Elisa Shua Dusapin and translated from French by Aneesa Abbas Higgins that is set at a South Korean resort.", "The award for young people\u2019s literature went to \u201cLast Night at the Telegraph Club\u201d by Malinda Lo, which follows a queer 17-year-old in San Francisco\u2019s Chinatown during the Red Scare as she falls in love for the first time. In her speech, she urged viewers to pay attention to their school boards and vote in local elections. \u201cWe need your support to keep our stories on our shelves. Don\u2019t let them erase us,\u201d she said.", "The foundation presented two lifetime achievement awards.", "Nancy Pearl, an author and librarian who has worked in public library systems in Detroit, Tulsa and Seattle, was the recipient of the Literarian Award, which recognizes service to the American literary community.", "Karen Tei Yamashita, the author of eight books, including \u201cSansei and Sensibility,\u201d \u201cTropic of Orange\u201d and \u201cLetters to Memory,\u201d received the Medal for Distinguished Contribution to American Letters, an award that has previously gone to Toni Morrison, Walter Mosley and Maxine Hong Kingston. Ms. Yamashita teaches literature and creative writing at the University of California, Santa Cruz.", "\u201cIdeas are dangerous and transformative,\u201d she said in her speech. \u201cWriting, then, is creative work for which we are responsible, accountable. Writing requires our constant care and integrity.\u201d"]
